title: 113_hr3130
content: The Act titled "Protect Family Values at the Border Act" aims to protect family values in apprehension programs. The "Protect Family Values at the Border Act" mandates procedures for migration deterrence programs at the border, requiring inquiries about family relationships and humanitarian concerns for apprehended individuals. The "Protect Family Values at the Border Act" mandates considerations for the physical safety and best interests of apprehended individuals and their children, prioritizing family unity and public interest factors in decisions regarding repatriation or prosecution. Mandatory training is required for relevant authorities. The "Protect Family Values at the Border Act" requires specialized training for U.S. Customs and Border Protection personnel on legal authorities and best practices related to the preservation of a child's best interest, family unity, and public interest factors. Border enforcement personnel must undergo periodic training on relevant policies and procedures. Additionally, the Secretary is required to submit an annual report to Congress on the impact of migration deterrence programs at the border. The Secretary must report to Congress on the effects of migration deterrence programs on parents, legal guardians, primary caregivers, individuals traveling with family members, and those with humanitarian concerns. The report should include the number of apprehended individuals who are parents or caregivers of U.S. citizen children and instances where both parents or the primary caregiver of a child were removed. The Secretary must report to Congress on the effects of migration deterrence programs, including the number of apprehended individuals traveling with family members and the impact on public interest factors. Regulations to implement this section must be promulgated within 120 days of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. LIMITING DANGEROUS DEPORTATION PRACTICES. The Secretary must certify to Congress every 180 days that individuals apprehended at the southern border are deported during daylight hours, with exceptions for compelling governmental interests. The Secretary must consult with relevant parties when negotiating deportation agreements for apprehended individuals, considering safety concerns and appropriate hours for deportations. SEC. 4. SHORT-TERM CUSTODY STANDARDS. The Secretary must establish short-term custody standards for CBP facilities within 180 days of the Act's enactment, ensuring basic care for individuals in custody and limiting detention space capacity except in emergencies. detainees must receive water and a snack. CBP custody must provide detainees with water, snacks, nutritious meals, access to bathroom facilities, basic toiletries, bedding, adequate lighting, climate control, and health screenings. Upon arrival in CBP custody, detainees must undergo a physical and mental health screening following National Commission for Correctional Health Care Jails Standards. Immediate health needs are addressed by a qualified professional, and detainees are informed of their right to make a phone call and provided with contact information for filing complaints. Upon arrival in CBP custody, detainees receive a health screening and are informed of their rights, including access to consular officials, counsel, and protections under the Prison Rape Elimination Act of 2003. The Commissioner of CBP ensures safe transport and reasonable accommodation for religious practices. Individuals in CBP custody have access to consular officials, counsel, and receive copies of signed documents. They are transferred to appropriate facilities or released within 48 hours. The Commissioner of CBP ensures constant surveillance of at-risk individuals and provides physical and mental health assessments for those in custody for more than 24 hours. (g) Inspection of Short-Term Custody Facilities.--Short-term custody facilities must undergo annual inspections by the Department of Homeland Security Office for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties, with results publicly disclosed. Nonperishable belongings confiscated from individuals in CBP custody must be returned before deportation or removal. The Secretary must establish regulations within 180 days to track individuals in CBP custody, educate them on legal rights, and ensure notification to oversight offices. The Secretary must report to Congress within 180 days and annually thereafter on all deaths of individuals in CBP custody or as a result of encounters with CBP, including investigation results. The Secretary must report to Congress on all deaths in CBP custody or as a result of encounters, including investigation results. Reports must also detail instances of serious injuries requiring hospitalization due to CBP use of force. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, key definitions include "apprehended individual" as someone caught by Homeland Security, "border" as a U.S. international border, "child" as defined in the Immigration and Nationality Act, "cooperating entity" as a State or local partner, "Department" as Homeland Security, and "migration deterrence program" as an action related to deterrence. The term "deterrence program" refers to actions related to repatriation or prosecution of apprehended individuals for Immigration and Nationality Act violations by the Secretary or a cooperating entity. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Homeland Security, and "unaccompanied alien child" is defined in the Homeland Security Act of 2002.
